comments.commentBody:
Here;e the problem. About 98% of all Africans want to come to the U.s. or Western Europe. About 85% of all the non-elite south of the border want to emigrate to El Norte. Add in a lot of rural Chinese, etc. and...where do we draw the line? We have a generous legal immigration program. A little too general. Last year, we accepted 1.5 MILLION legan immigrants, at a time when real unemployment in this country stood at 18%.

Sp, is there any COMMON SENSE left in our Congress. We should have a moratorium on legal immigration and an absolute ban on illegal immigration. Send them HOME!

Illegal immigrants are cloging hospitals in the southwest, clogging schools nationwide, and taking jobs away from skilled workers. (Sorry, only 2% are picking lettuce--check out the constructuion crews nationwide--lot cheaper than hiring Union Hall workers!).

But the politicians only see votes. The rest of us see a dreadful burden for years to come.

I cannot beleive our own federal government is sueing it's own citizens to benefit a group of non citizens. What happened to "By the people, for the people". U.S. citizens and States have no rights under federal law? WTH?

November is coming. This issue is a BIG loser for Democrats. As bad as the Republicans were, these arrogant Democrats are even worse. Throw the bums out in November. All incumbants, regardless of party. Keep doing that until government is once again representative.

I am always amazed that the ones who flaunt the Constitution so much are the very ones who deny it so strongly.  The ruling today is a confirmation of the Federal Government's obligations to the Constitution.  The judge ruled it is uncontitutional for a state to usurp the authority of the Federal Government in affairs of immigration.  THAT'S THE CONSTITUTION.  There's more to it than a misinterpretation of the second amendment.  If the Republicans want to do something about illigal immigration, let them support comprehensive immigration reform and stop using undocumented aliens as political footballs.

Of course, we need an updated and comprehensive national immigration law. So what's the hang up?

The Republicans, despite their feined support for the far right to kick all the illegals out, are stonewalling because their biggest business donors use illegal immigrant labor. Republican puppet masters have always liked the ambiguity of hating illegal immigrants while loving their cheap labor.

And the Democrats are stonewalling because they don't want to alienate Hispanics, labor unions and the rich Progressives who use undocumented nannies, housekeepers and gardeners.

We legal Americans created the job opportunities that drew our neighbors from south of the border to this country. Now we owe them a reasonable opportunity to become legal while ending the practice of looking the other way when it comes to cheap sources of labor.

We need a guest worker program and a mechanism to enable the undocumented workers who are here to get in line to become legal.

Today's ruleing should be a warning to the 70% of the people in the U.S. who are in favor of the imigration laws that the federal government will not protect us by enforceing them and they won't tolorate anyone else enforceing them ether. It does make you wonder who the Mexicians are paying off in D.C. though.

I've just read the first 35 comments, and here's what I find simply baffling: people seem to think that banning online gambling stops people from gambling online. It makes it slightly less convenient, but it doesn't stop anyone who really wants to do it from doing it.

Classic maneuver by the elites to continue to transfer the debt to the middle/poor class while doing whatever they can to privatize any profits for themselves and their financial supporters.  How about keeping corporations that don't pay taxes in this country (off shore corps) from doing business in this country, or closing the loopholes that allow many corporations and individuals who make millions from paying any taxes at all. The U.S. social programs pale in comparision to the corporate welfare.

It is not currently a federal crime for people to go online and start gambling. This isn't like drug laws, prostitution laws, etc where the threat is against the average person. The federal law targets the businesses, not the players. It is quite easy to get online right now and begin gambling. Two guys rent space in my office and have made a "career" out of playing Texas Hold-Em online. 4-8 hours a day, when they want, and that's all they do for income. If I was any good, I'd join 'em. But repealing the law won't change anything except where the money flows: U.S. coffers, or foreign coffers.

Gambling is just another form of entertainment. Its popularity continues to increase as nearly every state in the country allows casinos in some form. Its popularity will never decline, so it seems like a great way to raise revenue.

From my experience traveling around the country and visiting casinos, the vast majority of gamblers are not poor or hopelessly addicted. Alcohol causes far more problems than gambling.
Gambling is definitely not victimless. Ask the children of hardcore gamblers. As to it control by government, I have no opinion.

This article is mistitled. There was no 'thinking' involved in earlier discussions, and there is no re-thinking now.

What there was, and what there has been is panic, quick-fix straw-grasping, knuckling under, self-deception, frightening neurotic denial, and the fix.

See, gambling is not a Natural Resource or an Industrial Base. It takes, but cannot give back.

Spare us arguments that it has funded public education, Save-the-Puppy programs, or has been anything other than what it is - an economic and moral sinkhole.

I read about this debate, and imagine the backroom sessions, and I get scared. I hear it -and hear it a lot - from many people in the remains of our educated and aware middle class - that the Congress seems to have unplugged itself from the rest of the nation, from reality itself; that while we founder and flail, China is locking-up resources, signing hundred-year leases for croplands in Africa.

There is very little of any real value here anymore that is not owned by somebody else. The willed belief that Internet Poker will pay off or even service the viggorish owed to the Chinese, much less rebuild our poor betrayed country and shore its underpinnings with anything more than low-bid sand is simply insane. Not just self-serving, short-sighted, blind. Insane.

In addition to legalizing internet gambling, how about legalizing and controlling the distribution of narcotics ( including the cash crops from Afghanistan) The govt can impose a tax and sharp penalty for those who distribute a license. But once it is legalized, the price of narcotics would probably crash, and Al Qaeda will experience a sharp reduction of revenue.
Can marijuana be far behind???

Most of you are familiar with the famous saying: "one definition of insanity is doing the same thing over an over again and expecting a different result."

Sometimes people incapable of understanding this become problem gamblers. Although this is not true of poker where you can increase your skill and thus win more often. Anyone who still thinks poker is a game of mostly chance is ignorant of the game and/or the science studying the game over the last few years.

But a far more common example of otherwise normal people acting insane is the addiction to prohibition as model of how to control social behavior. It has never worked. Even in the most repressive regimes vices are/where still easily available. And especially given the US experience with alcohol prohibition, you'd think the people of the US would have learned something.

And many have. The overwhelming consensus among experts who study these fields is that if your goal is really to minimize harm, legalization and regulation is the way to go. And bringing the commercial aspect of the activity into the legal economy is a commercial benefit to society.

But you folks who don't like gambling and think it stupid or immoral still keep arguing it should be banned, even though all evidence is that such a response will result in more problems, not less. This can only be due to ignorance or the fact that moralists, whether of the right or left, enjoy seeing people suffer from doing things the moralists told them not to do.

Thank you House Financial Services Committee for, at least this once, seeing through the fear mongering and making the wisest choice.

I find it very interesting that the persistent financial crisis has forced American politicians to re-examine its previous policies towards societies ills. Funds are short in California: legalize and tax weed; Funds are short nation-wide: legalize and tax online gambling.  It really is quite amazing how these things that historically been view as anathema to America, are now being viewed realistically as a means of supporting failing budgets. It is about time that the US started taking a pragmatic and less moralistic view towards policy.

Ahhh, gambling. The desperation revenue raising tool of state governments when manufacturing goes overseas and government can't find the consensus (or can't get past the Party of No) to properly incentivize a real manufacturing option like green energy conversion.  This is a bad idea. Pretty soon, though, everyone has casinos and no one's making any money. Gambling is a nasty, corrupt business to begin with. Put it online and you breed a whole new crop of compulsives racking up credit card debt that ordinary folks end up paying for in higher fees. Put it online and all those glittering casinos in garden spots like Vegas, Atlantic City and elsewhere will take a big hit and real people lose jobs. I'll say it again -- bad idea.

Folks, gamblers are going to gamble, it's probably a genetic predisposition to risk-taking which would have served our species well in the early days. So it seems to me that having some legal form of gambling could be a big help; when they gamble illegaly, there's no taxes collected, and criminals often take advantage of them with crooked games and broken kneecaps.

So by all means, legalize, regulate, and tax internet gambling. Might as well get some benefit from the stupidly self-destructive, or the wasteful dilettantes.
online gambling is already huge - might as well get some tax money instead of sending it overseas

Here we go again our law makers are a not thinking of long term development. Just give more access to compulsive gamblers, then ask the taxpayer to pick up the bills and taxes that will not be collected.

Which is worse, gambling or drugs? Put it another way for the Obama clan which one can you make the most money on? Forget the gambling go for the drugs and legalize it, tax it, use it, put the cartels out of business and save a bundle on law enforcement which is not doing the job anyway.
What kind of economics does the Obama crowd think they are employing, this president is losing his mind while we are losing our country.

More taxes, more taxes, more taxes!   It's sad how many articles I write the same droll lines about.  MTA, wants to charge me more!  Hotel's want to increase occupancy tax and charge us more!  NY State wants to charge me more to have a Coke! Sounds to me like we have duped and our money has been mis-managed for 20 plus years!

Poker may not be considered as unadulterated gambling.

Online poker should be legalized and be monitored for fairness to the players!
More Casino Economics..!  Mo Green-span must be glad..!

Everything you do is 'gambling,' in a sense. Games of strategy such as poker are similar to other strategic decisions you make of the course of the day... except that poker can actually can make you feel good.

I have more of a problem with those of you who believe they know what is better for others than they themselves do, than people having the option of doing something legally that they will do anyhow. I consider myself pretty liberal, but telling adults what they can and can not do because you "know" better is the height of hypocrisy. Legalize everything.
